snippet: The four soldiers and six police officers released were believed to be the last noncivilian captives held by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as the FARC.
abstract: Rebel group Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia releases four soldiers and six police officers it had held hostage for as long as 14 years; release is likely to feed hopes for peace talks between the rebel group and the Colombian government, but analysts say the two sides are still far from achieving mutual trust.

byline.original: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and JENNY CAROLINA GONZÁLEZ
byline.contributor: William Neuman reported from Caracas and Jenny Carolina González from Bogotá, Colombia.

lead_paragraph: The four soldiers and six police officers released were believed to be the last noncivilian captives held by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as the FARC.

headline.main: Colombian Rebels Free 10, Raising Hopes of Peace Talks With Government
headline.print_headline: Colombian Rebels Free 10, Raising Hopes of Peace Talks With Government
